# combination lock

## Background

_We've all seen combination locks like this one: ![lock](data:image/jpeg;base64,)._

_Let's make a class that can churn out these suckers._

_These will be simple locks - all you can really do with them is turn the dial to your target number - turning left or right isn't a thing here._

_To make it a bit more interesting, we'll also say that for these particular locks, if you set the dial to a particular number, the lock will unlock; otherwise, it will stay locked._

## Instructions

We're going to change gears here and start having you to write more code from scratch.

The drill contains just the documentation for the public methods required to pass the tests - you have to do the rest.

The name of your class should be **CombinationLock**.

If you decide to make any helper methods, they should be **private and non-static**.

## Testing Notes

> `currentNumber_is0_whenLockIsNew`
> 
> The current number showing on a brand new lock should be 0.

> `currentNumber_is10_when_turnTo10`
> 
> If we take a new lock and turn it to 10, its current number should be 10.

> `currentNumber_is20_when_turnTo10_then_turnTo20`
> 
> If we take a new lock and turn it to 10, and then turn it to 20, its current number should be 10.

> `currentNumber_is20_when_turnedTo20_then_turnedToNegative_then_turnedTo40`
> 
> If we take a new lock and turn it to 20, and then turn it out of range both below 0 and above 39, the current number should still be 20.

> `isUnlocked_isFalse_when_numberThatUnlocksIs17_andLockIsBrandNew`
> 
> A brand new lock that unlocks on 17 should be locked when it is first created (since its current number is 0).

> `isUnlocked_isFalse_when_numberThatUnlocksIs17_andLockIsTurnedTo16`
> 
> A brand new lock that unlocks on 17 should be locked when it is turned to 16.

> `isUnlocked_isFalse_when_numberThatUnlocksIs17_andLockIsTurnedTo16Then17Then16`
> 
> A brand new lock that unlocks on 17 should be locked when it is turned to 16, then 17, then 16.

> `isUnlocked_isFalse_when_numberThatUnlocksIs17_andLockIsTurnedTo16Then17Then16`
> 
> A brand new lock that unlocks on 17 should be locked when it is turned to 16, then 17, then 16.

> `isUnlocked_isTrue_when_numberThatUnlocksIs17_andLockIsTurnedTo16Then17`
> 
> A brand new lock that unlocks on 17 should be locked when it is turned to 16, then 17.

> `isUnlocked_isTrue_when_numberThatUnlocksIs0_andLockIsBrandNew`
> 
> A brand new lock that unlocks on 0 should be unlocked.
